messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 20, 2019 - November 26, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-11-27T18:48:32Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-11-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-11-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20191127-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-11-21T21:00Z to 2019-11-22T03:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-11-20.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~625 km/s on 2019-11-22.

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-11-24.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2019-11-25.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-11-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-12-03T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-11-27.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-11-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-11-19T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The recently numbered active region 12752 is the only one visible in the available imagery and it has low magnetic complexity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-11-16.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 30, 2019 - November 05, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-11-06T19:38:26Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-10-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-11-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20191106-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-10-31T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with a combination of an arrival of a S-type (<500 km/s) CME that started on 2019-10-25T05:54Z with a diffuse coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2019-10-29 and 2019-10-30, respectively.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to the lingering effects of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-10-24.  The flux dropped below the threshold level around 2019-10-30 and has remained nominal for rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-11-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-11-12T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The active regions present on the solar surface have low magnetic complexity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate or the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-11-10.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer
